title: How do I stop wage garnishment without do a bankruptcy
question: 25,000 lawsuit on a car I never drove
answers: Mr. Stempler's answer is as good as it gets without filing bankruptcy. I would ask why not bankruptcy? You may think it can't help you but if you haven't consulted an experienced bankruptcy attorney who has carefully reviewed all your facts, you might miss out on valuable protections.

My legal guide explains filing a claim of exemption, which stops garnishment without bankruptcy, though the judgment will remain collectible for at least 10 years or until satisfied in full. Linked below is my legal guide on making wage garnishment bearable and other tips to reduce the garnishment amount. Also below are the legal forms that you will need to prepare: WG-006 and WG-007. To resolve the underlying judgment, perhaps you were not served and the judgment can be set aside? For this review, consult with a debt collection DEFENSE attorney.

By: Robert Stempler (please see DISCLAIMER below)

A Professional Law Corporation

A bankruptcy is the best way to stop the garnishment. There are a few other things you can do though. Have you filed a claim of exemption? There are also objections to the garnishment that you can file with the court. You really should contact an attorney who can help you with this.
